item.title: Biden has to decide soon whether to sanction Venezuela. Here's what to know
item.description: Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro's government faces a deadline this week — to commit to holding free and fair elections or face renewed U.S. oil sanctions.

item.title: Report: China continues to subsidize deadly fentanyl exports
item.description: Fentanyl made from Chinese chemicals is killing tens of thousands of Americans. A House committee report found new evidence the Chinese government supports tax breaks to subsidize the drug trade.

item.title: Iran hails attack on Israel as a 'victory'; Photos of Sudan, 1 year into a brutal war
item.description: Iran says its attack against Israel was a success, despite the fact that 99% of the drones were intercepted. A Sudanese photographer documents how war has upended life in his country.

item.title: Suicides make up majority of gun deaths, but remain overlooked in gun violence debate
item.description: Suicide is the leading cause of gun-related deaths in the United States. But it's often only an afterthought in the public debate about gun violence.

item.title: NPR suspends veteran editor as it grapples with his public criticism
item.description: NPR has suspended Senior Editor Uri Berliner after he wrote an essay accusing the public radio network of becoming too progressive in its news coverage and losing the public's trust.

item.title: A new generation is uncovering the tiny doodles left by engineers on old microchips
item.description: Engineers left these drawings as a way to sign their work. Many are puns that made them chuckle to themselves. Now social media has rediscovered them and hobbyists try to keep that history alive.

item.title: Why homeless people are losing health coverage in Medicaid mix-ups
item.description: Nearly 130,000 Montanans lost Medicaid coverage during recent eligibility reviews. People who are homeless are more likely to have chronic health issues and particularly vulnerable to losing coverage.
